A good challenge to keep the muscles limber and the heart rate up, as well as expanding my skill set. I am not some aging fitness fan…I am overweight, work at a desk, heck, I am a type 2 diabetic…so this is how I plan to stay alive and relatively healthy. Now I don’t expect to become some fearsome sparring monster in tang soo do. I don’t even have any great notion of going for second dan in aikido. I just do this because it is great fun and I love it, and as long as I can drag my bones onto the mat, I will keep doing it. So yes, you can starting practicing martial arts in your damn 20s ;-)

You are the perfect age to get started. And don't worry about being skinny and unathletic.  The martial arts is all about using what you do have - not what you don't have. Ninjitsu is a very interesting martial art...moving in shadows. You may want to check out Stephen Hayes site: Stephen K. Hayes' Ninja Self Defense  It would be cool to connect with him...and then move to Japan and train with some of the guys he recommends. Per choosing a martial art or a school, it's all about the teacher.  So visit a few, meet the teacher(s), the students, etc.  The that feels like 'home' is the one. Let me know if I can help with anything. JKerr

Yes. You can start learning at any age. If you start today, in 10 years you’ll become a master of your art. There will be times when you wish you started when you were 16 years old but nothing beats hard work and dedication. Go for it! My instructor started learning in his early 30’s I believe. After ten years of hard work he’s got a successful self-defence training school, he teaches hundreds of people a year in seminars and many students view him as as one of the best in the country. So yes, you can start at your age and become very, very good.

I'd say never. Sure you might not be at the level expected of your age and sure you may not be that skilled at the beginning but, martial arts is all about working on your mind and body. Because of that, you can start any time to improve your discipline while also improving your overall physical well being. Besides, some of the best MMA/UFC fighters are in there mid 40s and they're still kicking it. The only thing that could limit how well you do at martial arts is how you think. If you let your mind be calm and relaxed with no expectations for failure or success, you'll be surprised as to what your body can achieve. P.S, a lot of old men and women in china practice tai chi (a martial art) to stay fit and maintain a good body so believe me they can attest that anyone at any age could start learning martial arts.

I took my first step onto the mat at age 48. I raced bicycles for many years so I had a little bit of conditioning. I was a bar brawler in my 20’s and 30’s so I had plenty of experience getting beat up. The way it went was: Kido wanted to try karate so he goes down and takes the free week of lessons. He loves it so we enroll him. Everyday I would drive him down to the studio and sit on the bench and watch the training. At the time I worked with a guy that was a higher ranked Taekwondo guy.We would talk about what kido was learning. One day he turns to me and says “I’d love to have your son and you at my school but since you are already going down there, sitting for 1–2 hours a day why don’t you get your ass out onto the mat?” I didn’t do it that day but a few weeks later I put on a gi, tied my white belt around my waist and never looked back. So is 23 to late, absolutely not.

no. But there are probably more constructive things you could do. Imagine, if you start now, you will have to meet 000s of masters and experts, who do not realise they are trying to train you in something that was probably developed as a method to stop the monks from sleeping all day and atrophying the muscles. Do weightlifting, far superior bang for your hours, increase bone density, strength etc. Statistically less injuries per hour trained in weightlifting. Of course if it is for the adrenalin then I reccomend taking up a bit of grappling, then boxing. Kicking really hurts after age 35 especially when receiving.

There’s no such thing as too old! :) I used to study with a guy when I was a teenager, he rang me last Xmas and asked to join my class this year - he’s in his late 70’s and had just undergone open heart surgery. He now trundles along with the rest of us - sure there are things he can’t do, but he has a great time and his fitness is improving - the other students love the guy, it’s been good for everybody. Pick an art which suits your physical ability, and go from there. For instance, as a teenager, classical jujutsu was easy - I had the flexibility, no problem. Last weekend, I attended a seminar with two very skilled Finnish jujutsu teachers and found that 30 years on, I can’t do that stuff any more. Too many injuries, can’t bend like I used to. That’s why I practice a low kicking, stand up art - I have the physical capabilities to be very good at what I study. You will too - just find the right thing.

I’m trying to self teach myself gymnastics. So far, totally failing at it. But I have made progress! It takes self discipline and will power in order to take on a task. However, I understand the embarrassment you may feel if you were to ask an instructor who teaches students beginning at a young age. But honestly they may feel honored that someone at your age has the desire to partake in this journey. Don’t live a life full of regrets. Go for it all. Take the shot. Take the chance. Do something that makes you feel physically strong and empowered. P.S.- The reason I don’t partake in classes myself is because of several complicated issues that would arise. But you on the other hand, man, take it from me another 16 year old, get the damn classes. Its so much easier when you have a mentor at your back who will encourage and implement the discipline within you. (The equipment is a plus.)

It depends on your goals in martial arts. Run for olympic games? You should start with Judo as a five year old kid. You will not get that experience from championships and after 35 you will not qualify. You just want to catch the feeling of getting into the ring? There are plenty competitions for boxing with guys older than 30 in their first fight as well as senior white belt tournaments. Self-defence? It´s never to late. Get a black belt for your bucket list? Go for it, in many dojos are senior students.

I started Karate at around your age, decided it was a waste of time. Tried BJJ aged 29, tried judo and got injured. Took a break. Came back to BJJ at 31 and continued on with wrestling and the odd bit of muay thai/MMA. I’m 35 now. I’m a three stripe blue belt in BJJ which is pretty respectable. I am in really good shape. I can keep up with the “youngsters” as long as I train smart (eat right, sleep, tap early and often). I wish I’d started younger, but I most certainly don’t feel old on the mats. At 26 you’re the perfect age to not only learn, but do well if you choose to compete.

When I started at my old kenpo school, the green and brown belts were almost all in their late thirties or forties. When they did jumping jacks together, their collective knees sounded like a bowl of Rice Krispies. But they all trained hard and with great enthusiasm. You are a long, long way from being too old.

For me you can never be too old.  Those who are enlightened never stop forging themselves. The realizations of such masters cannot be expressed well in words or theories. The most perfect action echo the patterns found in nature.  ~Morihei Ueshiba Below is a blog post I recently wrote about my 30-40 years in Martial arts with various ups and downs on the martial path.  My First Step On The Martial Arts Path and The Fallen Idols

No not at all ! As a matter of fact you should start. I know people who started at the age of 60. There is no age limit. But don’t expect to be a competitive fighter. I advice you to start with Aikido. It’s less physical and the training is relatively easy. It will boost your confidence and help you to believe that you can do it. After a year of training Aikido , start practicing Kendo. You will have fun and improve your body
Nah - When You’re 80 You’ll be a Master ! Like Helen Dugan. [1]  Footnotes[1] 80-Year-Old Karate-Chopping Grandma Is Making The World A Better Place

6 years ago I had one student coming to my academy. He was 22 years old, 157 kg and had an IT company. Only did basketball in his teenage years. Now he is 28 years old, 110 kg, still has the IT company and has 4 World Titles (Brazilian Jiu Jitsu and Japanese Ju Jitsu) and 5 European Titles (white belt, blue belt, 2 x purple belt, brown belt in BJJ).It depends a lot on what martial art you start and what is your goal. There are plenty of martial arts that depend a lot on the physical attributes. Others not so much, but more on the technical aspect.

The only thing that could possibly stop you is ego, if you have your ego under control then it's never too late. Remember that like everything else BJJ takes time to learn and a long long time to master, during that journey you will have to submit many many times to guys and girls that are younger, smaller etc. And as long as you stick with it you will improve, just stick with it. Your fitness level will also improve very very quickly! Good luck

In addition to what Kent has said, I would add that most people start learning the "internal" martial arts when they are much older than 25.  I don't have any data, but I'd guess the average age for starting to learn Tai Chi is forty-something.  Seems to me like most people who learn Tai Chi / Bagua / Hsing Li do so later in life, often as a second or third art. As with all skills, a lot of it comes down to how much you are willing to invest - practice time and willingness to listen and learn.

It really depends on your condition… For some people the age of 30 is already late… A real life example I know of is the late Chen Taiji master Gao Fu, a gracious lady I met when she was 80 years old. She was at the time one of the most renowned masters in Beijing. She told me that she started practicing well into her sixties… And she was not doing slow, soft Taiji, but the traditional Chen style full with jumps and explosive force.  a picture of hers when I met her…

Depends on what you're learning it for. Primary tournament age bracket in sport karate, for example, is 18-34, so if you want to compete, you're not too late to build a small trophy collection, but you will have to work for it. For most other applications, there are no age limits. There might be physical limits, especially in acrobatics-heavy styles, but most karate (and most kung fu for that matter) shouldn't be a problem.

For questions that start with “Is X too old to learn…” the answer is nearly always “no”. Two of my best friends, a husband and wife, both took up martial arts when their kids wanted to take it up. They are now a family of black belts. 18 might be the perfect age to take it up. You’re nearly fully grown physically, and you have enough time to dedicate to it so that you can master the fundamentals, before things like a career and family start competing for your time.

No, it's never late to start! Taekwondo is all about personal self improvement both mentally and physically. There are many gains to do taekwondo at any age: you improve concentration, stamina, mental control, physical strength, flexibility, coordination, and life long friends. Also, there are many people that start doing taekwondo at a later age, so you don't have to worry about being the only one your age starting out. Please don't ever feel that your age is a deterrent to starting martial arts. Martial Arts is a beautiful art that can be experienced at any stage in life!

Absolutely not. You may want to research clubs that caters to mixed ability levels as a minority of places are really only designed for ultra-competitive fighters. However, most martial arts clubs I have been a part of would gladly work with any student, from elite combat athletes through to casual hobbyists, older people trying to keep fit, even young kids and people with disabilities. I'm sure you will be able to find somewhere that suits your needs.

I was 34 when I started practicing karate (now 37 almost) and depending on what your goal is I have to say: no. You are never to old to learn or master this.As some other people already posted, only your body could be less fit, but practicing these martial arts, it will come back with you. Depending on your current fitness, it might take longer than a younger one.It also depends on your expectation, what do you considder "mastering a martial art"?

I started Taekwondo at 40. I am now 46, and taking my Second Dan black belt test in three months. You will probably never become a world champion, but that is true of any physical activity you take up after thirty. You can still become pretty good if you put the work in. Leave your ego at the door for the first few months. There will be 12-year-olds who can do things you can’t. But you have size and strength on your side. I wish I had started ten years earlier.

wow!! have you heard about old guys living in china …..yes yes.. the tai chi stuff but forget…… it is too much old stuff ( not offending ) let me tell you a new story …there is a trainer named Shane Fazen from Philadelphia ..a new man 63 years old asked him the question — can i learn martial arts? i am 63 years , i am fat , never did a physical exercise or anything like that ……….now he is 65 years ……and guess what!! he learned mauy thai !!!! (one of the most physically demanding martial art!! its so physically demanding that even young men get tired and gas out and even vomiting!! during training !!) so he learned mauy thai and he is throwing head kicks , back elbow etc etc …. so no no no no no no no no no you are never too old to learn martial arts !! until and unless you do not die !! so you can and definitely should learn martial arts !! its a part of life

Depends on what you mean by "master".  You can certainly get quite good at it, instructor-level no problem.  I started kendo at 22, and now at 6 dan I am a reasonably competent player and instructor.  But I don't believe I will ever have as smooth and natural a motion as those who started when they were kids.  I'm definitely not going to be a world champion.  There's a theory that physical skills acquired before late teens are associated with brain development, ie there are neural pathways devoted to that skill, where as those developed as an adult are learned behaviour.  Hard-wiring vs software if you will.  Anyway, that's my excuse.  But you shouldn't let it stop you from enjoying martial arts, I don't regret it at all and remain quite active in both kendo and judo at age 52.

You’d be too old only if you’re so old you’re physically incapable of being active, and even then, who’s to say?? Other than that, I’d say you’re still able to start martial art training.  There’re tons of stories of “older” people who got their start in martial arts relatively later in life, so you have many role models!

There is no “too late,” to study martial arts. I`m 40, and I jog and I practice BJJ and Kickboxing. I`m in better shape than a lot of people my age. And fairly confident that I can defend myself against someone my own size, even someone a bit bigger than me. Just do a little bit each day, or do what you can…even just once or twice a week. *And don`t measure yourself against professional you see on tv, they are young, naturally athletic and they do nothing BUT mma. As long as you practice something, you`re eventually going to get better. Martial arts are great for all people, of all ages. If I can give one simple peace of advice, it`s this; make sure you jog, or ride a bike…or do SOME kind of aerobic training along with a martial art. Martial arts techniques are nearly useless if you don`t get yourself into some kind of half decent shape. You don`t have to be a marathon runner, just try to be better than yourself last week. M

I would say the same as every one else. I am 23 and I restarted my Taekwondo classes after 13 years of gap (did my Yellow belt in 2000). And I will tell you I curse my decision of quitting back then. As far as the performance goes, I still workout to be better than most teenagers in the school, with no stamina or zeal. Also, there are afew students in my school who are in late 20s/ early 30s.So, the deal is to stop thinking and start kicking!! Good luck :)

I remember reading Black Belt many years ago about a women who was getting on and using canes to help her walk, she was late 60’s. And she wanted to learn Karate. The story goes she went to one of Chuck Norris’ places and he adapted the style to suit her. 3 years later she got a black belt and ended up a honorary bouncer in her local senior citizens club, so no you are never to old to learn.

If you have jogged every day, or workout weekly sure the Arts are great for you. It will slow the deterioration of memory cells and keep your awareness shape. It can slow arthritis or become a means of treating it. Karate, Tae Kwon Do, Hapiko, Krav Maga are all out of the picture though. Those Arts depend a lot on muscular strength and at this point, the body doesn’t have the recovery ability to train effectively. The same can be said with a few of the Southern Styles of Kung Fu as well. The Wudang schools are of course ideal. like Taijiquan, Bakuachang, and Xinyi. Other schools like Aikido also have therapeutic abilities and low impact curriculums for all ages to enjoy.

If I'm not, you definitely are not. I'm 47, have been training martial system's for 39 years, and teaching for 25. I recently picked up training my 10th system and just passed my yellow belt test. I know that's quite a bit of personal information, but I wanted to show that despite your age or experience level, you can always learn more. If you want it, go after it. Don't let silly things like age, physical form or other people's opinions stand in your way. I hope this helps.

Learning has no age, you can start learning at the age of 5 or at the age of 50. Martial art is no different, it is just an art which you can perfect through practice and proper guidance. You are just in your late teenage and its not late to start learning a martial art. Choose a style you want to learn and also a reputed club and start your lessons soon. Don't waste your time thinking og starting, get ur ass up and start training.. Best of luck.

Absolutely not. You can begin studying martial arts and ANY age. We have dozens of students at my academy who began in their 30s and 40s. Several now compete in tournaments and consistently win medals. They may not have started early enough to win gold at Worlds, but they are still extremely proficient. At your age, you have plenty of time to reach your full potential. If yo are interested I would absolutely pursue whatever art you are interested in. I doubt you will regret it.

No. I started at the tender age of 40. I didn't choose a gentle system, either, lol. I began with Okinawan karate, which is extremely tough, if done properly. After many years, I then crosstrained into Kung Fu, and studied that for several years. Due to osteoporosis, I have retired, and I miss it terribly! You are. Never top old!! Good luck to you!

I am not sure how old you are, but if you are in your twenties or thirties, the answer is: NO, ABSOLUTELY NOT!!! As long as you have the self-discipline, commitment and willpower to learn new things, age is not a factor in how much you can achieve. I can assure you there are people in their senior years who are still being shown the ropes on various martial arts.

Yes, you can learn martial arts at eighteen for as long as your body works properly you can always learn new things. One of the the highest black belts in my classes is 63. He only started like 20 years ago and is older than our Sifu! In fact the choice to start is what saved his life as he had a sudden heart attack/stroke. According to the doctors they wouldn't be able to do what needed to be done if he hadn't been in such good shape.

Definitely not. I do admit that most of the national champions and Olympic medalists I trained with over the years started as young children there are plenty of people who didn’t start until they were much older. I can name several individuals who didn’t start training until they were in their mid 30’s. But if you need some motivation

No age is too late. There have been several notable masters in various styles who did not begin their education until well into middle age. If you mean to be competitive in the world of combat sports, yes you are starting quite late, but depending on your physical capacity, your discipline, the level of your dedication, and the quality of your instruction, anything is possible. But, you must become obsessed, through and through.

Not at all. I began karate at the age of 34. Im now 43 and a second dan black belt. If you're in reasonably good shape and apply yourself diligently, there is nothing to prevent you from being a capable martial artist. But be aware of your limitations. For example, a kicking art becomes difficult if you begin late, as flexibility becomes an issue. Your body structure is also important ie are you lean, heavyset etc. To ensure longevity in the sport, be smart in your training. You will not recover from injury as easily as an 18 year old. Hope this helps

Yes, u can learn karate…thare is no such age bar of learning something even there is also a benefit of learning karate at elder age is that u can grasp the techniques and logic behind those more convincingly than learning in a more younger age, every belt gradation exam is generally held in 6 months and there are total ten belts( shotokan karate) so u need 5years to become a black belt holder…..just go for it…age is just a number….

Where I go there's a man who started at the age of 65. He's much farther into the system than I am, an eighteen year old who started at 6.   As a side note, he recently had to state his age during a ceremony and proudly said "72 and three quarters." Age means nothing.

No. 18 is a great age to start learning. You have the ability to not only practice the techniques, but also to understand them, and to have an understanding of the art you choose. You will also be able to gain a much better insight into the martial art than if you started at a younger age and weren’t fully competent or understanding of it.

You can learn a martial art as long as you can stand and breathe. Twenty-two is very young. Your body still has flexibility and speed. You would even be able to compete if you trained hard enough. But as for learning a martial art simply for exercise or self defense, age is no barrier. The older you get the harder it is to master an art as your body just won't respond the same way, but the age where that starts to have an impact is a long way away from 22.

It takes 10,000 hours to become one of the best in the world at something. If you put 10,000 hours into a martial art you will be one of the best in the world. Even if your reflexes aren't in olympic shape by that age, your technique will be at that level... it takes a lot less than that to "master" a martial art (or it's something you can never quite get to, since there is always more to learn, depending on your perspective). Like Jorge I started Taekwondo at 33, not quite to black belt, but very close, and I destroyed in the middle there, so had to take some time off.

It's really never too late to learn a martial art but it is sometimes too late for a person to maybe delve into certain aspects of learning it or doing certain things. Heavy or hard contact sparring for instance is not something I would recommend for older individuals in their training. People as they get older just don’t heal up as well and as quickly as when they are younger and so there are some aspects to learning a martial art that they would be better to avoid.

It depends on the art. I would recommend you start with tai chi chuan, then maybe aikido. Both are very deep arts and work together, if you have a skillful instructor in each, and can be used for self-defense if that is specifically taught. If you want to go into karate or other hard style, you may have trouble with it. I am 56 and just do not want to do all those things I used to do with Shotokan and Goju ryu, even though I think it would be so cool to be able to still pull them off. But now, to be realistic, tai chi is my best bet. Aikido my very close second choice. If all you want is self defense, there are courses on just that, so you don’t have to engage in a formal art at all.

You are never to old to learn martial arts. the older you are the more you will be able to learn from it. just go in with a open mind and don’t act like you know everything. it’s helpful to instructors when you are willing to learn and follow their instructions.

No matter how old or young, no matter if you are starting your first class or have been practicing everyday for 40 years, you may  never feel like you've "mastered" a martial art. There is always more to learn, more to perfect.  The beauty of the martial arts is you and the art are always evolving. And mastery is always relative. The more you learn the more you'll realize how much more there is to master.  Good luck!

You can learn martial arts anytime, age does not matter here but u have to choose your style accordingly and find a very good master who can teach you the essence of the style not just do some movements and achieve some medals and belts so that u can brag about it to everybody.

"Master" is an extraordinarily strong word, so I would ask what you mean by that. You can become proficient, you can find a movement system you enjoy, you can possibly learn to defend yourself. There is no age that is "too old" to start most of the accessible systems.  I would say that what is said about martial arts and age is analogous to any movement system.  Is 25 too old to aspire to be a prima ballerina?  Yes.  Is it too old to take up Argentine Tango and become amazing at it?  Not at all.   There is a great quote in one of Rory Miller's books that goes, "Train in something that makes it a joy to move" and another by Ueshiba, "Never begin with results."  I wrote a blog post about picking a martial art school that can be found here: "What Martial Art Should I Study?"

Absolutely not. As some others have mentioned you'll want to pick an art that works with your physical ability. At 50 I would stay away from TKD, Wushu, and MMA. These arts are physically intense and lend themselves to younger people. You might try Ju Jitsu, Kung Fu, or Aikido depending on what type of skills you desire. Bottom line is as long as you're still breathing you can still learn and get better. Just look for an instructor who is willing and able to give you modifications if needed, due to any physical limitations. Best of luck on your martial journey!

50 today is still considered “young” for many today. Therefore, depending on how fit you are and how much time you have will determine your success in learning. Also, you may likely have to train smarter (not harder) than the average 20 year old practitioner but still go for it if you can. “You” are your only motivator or obstacle.

As a fellow skinny 16 year old male, I feel obligated to help. No, it's not too late to start martial arts at 16. What you start though really depends on what kind of places you have near you. Look up what some disciplines practiced around your area are and what dojos teach them, since you cant learn something like martial arts on your own. If you want a more concrete answer, what you want will depend on how much time you are willing to sink into learning. I myself started with boxing which evolved into later learning many different disciplines since boxing gives you a great base to work from. If you're willing to put some time into learning and commit to it, try to find a place that teaches muay thai, wrestling, or brazilian jujitsu. All three of them are great things to learn, with wrestling being the easiest to find and muay thai being the closest to the 'ninja feel' that you wanted since most martial arts that claim to be 'ninja like' are either impractical or useless in the long run.

Concisely: No. There might be certain, very specific, but very few, goals that you might not be able to achieve if you didn’t begin early enough. But, one could prove that wrong too. I’m 28, have practiced Filipino Martial Arts for the last year, and am planning on starting Brazilian Jiu Jitsu. Two disciplines i can assure you any 70 year old could begin training in. In fact, I know of wheelchair bound folk who figured a way to train. What’re you worried about?

No. It's never too late to start. It's still a good age but the thing is that you need to work a lot on yourself. Physically and mentally. If You still have it in you, then definitely you can. Just never give up it will take time and hardship but I bet you will become a good Martial artist. In 1–2 years with a regular practice & persistence. All the best . :)

You never 'master' a martial art. It is not a destination but a journey. You are never too old. No matter what your age, ability or past experience you can always learn and improve both physically and mentally. So when is the right time to start? NOW!

Yes, of course, you can learn martial arts. Age is just a number for learning anything. If you are interested in learning you can definitely learn martial arts. The minimum age limit of starting martial arts is 13 or 14. So, your age is mature and good enough for learning it. The most important thing, needed for learning is your interest and hard practicing. Just give your time and learn the skills and you will become a strong and confident personality.

Ooooh snap! Sorry you can't. Martial arts are only for people who are 22 or under or 24 or over. It's not me telling you it's that international law that doesn't exist! Seriously tho I. There is literally 0 problems with you starting at 23. It's good if you do it and it will increase your quality of life. It will be harder if you want to go pro, but still possible.

No, if you have the will power to work hard, you can learn Taekwondo, Karate or any other Martial Art, at any age. There is no specific age limit to learn Martial Art. But, learning Martial Art (Taekwondo, karate, Muyo thai, etc.) at a very young age does has an advantage, that, you get the flexibility of your body, just say while stretching out or practicing the kicks. But don’t worry, keep a positive vibe and work hard. Nothing is impossible. Good luck !  Thanks for reading. :)

No no no no you are never to old to learn, I started at 40 and was the best thing I could have done. If you want to go in to sports karate then you should have started young but for yourself to be fit and learn to defend yourself never to old. At my dojo a dad started to do karate after a year his son did and he is 47. So age is just in the mind

I started martial arts when I was 7, got my black bell at 12 and second degree black bell at 17. At college I started a new martial art. Another student who has never done martial arts started the same time. He could take on my 12 year old self. By the time we graduate the only thing my 17 year old self will have on him is tenacity. Early martial arts isn't worthless, but as you mature you can make more out of your instruction. It is never too late to start.

No 18 is a good age to start. Find a school with a good reputation and try it out. Keep in mind some schools are tougher than others. Do you want a good workout or do you want to be a great fighter? You’ll figure it out. Some people prefer striking/kicking, others like grappling/wrestling, other like both. Have a great journey!

Age is not an issue! But you should consult a doctor if you’ve got health problems. It will take 5 years of regular training to be really good at what is it that you are doing, and 9 to 10 years to master it. On top of that, you’ve got to keep yourself physically fit. I would suggest you find a good instructor who teaches Brazilian Jiu-jitsu. There are plenty of phony ones, so beware. BJJ will teach you enough to defend yourself in a fight.

No. No age is too old to benefit from martial arts. If you mean too old to compete at a high level, if you are an elite natural athlete, then your physical tools are an advantage to make up for experience, and if you have quality training and the time to train and good nutrition and live clean (not missing workouts or getting crap ones because you were out drinking all night), then no, 23 is still young enough to make up plenty of ground. Look at 23 as 3 to 6 years before the body's natural peak.

It really depends on which martial art you are talking about. I wouldn’t recommend arts like Judo or Muay Thai (or Kyokushin Karate, for that matter) if you are getting older, as they are very hard on your body. Tai Chi and Aikido are fine, though Aikido can be hard on knees. Many Karate schools don’t do contact sparring, and so are fairly safe. Basically look at a martial art like any other sport. Look at the training and see if your body can take it.

No. I’m 72, and a Tai Chi student. I started when I was 64. Martial arts study is healthy, and increases energy and stamina. It makes you “younger.” I hear this is true pretty much across the board, My own experience is with Tai Chi and Qigong, with the Chinese arts, and I know this is true of them, because energy management is an essential part of their foundation.

It depends on the martial art but if you’re willing to get in shape, put in the time and work with your current limitations and understand it will take time to surpass them, then go train! I highly recommend Brazilian Jiu Jitsu. A guy I know started after he was 40. He’s a purple belt now at the age of 50.

I started Martial Arts in my mid 20s. Yes, you can start to learn at any age. In some ways, being a bit more adult can help because you can concentrate more on things. Good luck. Just found this article: https://www.womenshealth.com.au/how-to-start-taekwondo
Unless you bedridden never. Nastiest artist I ever met was about 90 and looked late fifties Combat sports though different - you not going to be great after late thirties

I started at age 27. By age 32 I was in the best shape ever. I was also frequently complimented by sparring partners (although I seldom won. *shrug* ) So I guess that means I made them work hard for their wins. :-) I did it for exercise and mental discipline. It worked wonderfully on both counts.  So it's never too late. Not even if you were in your 60s or 70s. (That's not to say you reap the same benefits, but there's almost always a benefit.)

I am 45 and I just started! If you are healthy, able and responsible what does age have to do with it? I am going to be busting my ass until I am 70 if that is what it takes to get my black belt. Obviously not. There is no specific age bar for learning Martial Arts.Its for all human being for their self betterment. But choose a school according to your aspirations.Thank you
